messages.text: In a single year, temperature jumps around from month to month with no particular pattern.
The average global temperature jumps around from year to year. It's hard to see any pattern when looking at only a handful of years.
Several decades of temperature records don't always show whether the planet is warming or cooling.
You can begin to see patterns of climate change can be seen when looking at 40 years of records or more.
When viewing over a century of global temperature records, a clear warming trend is observed.

annotations.text: From the 1940s to 1975, aerosols from pollution and volcanic eruptions cool planet slightly.
In 1975, warming starts to accelerate, driven by human CO2 emissions.
Starting around 1979, the rate of warming increases to 0.3°C (0.5°F) per decade.
In 1998 a strong El Niño event boosts warming from greenhouse gases, breaking 118 years of heat records.
In 2003, a historic heat wave in Europe kills 70,000 people.
In 2005, average temperature breaks the 1998 record.
2016 is the hottest year on record.
